items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: Tides remain high for tonight's tide. Forecast high water is 21:30 on 08/10/21 with a level of 7.44 mAOD and a Force 1 Easterly wind. Tomorrow morningâ€™s tide is not forecast to reach flood alert thresholds. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. There is a possibility of high water levels for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible but properties are not expected to flood at this point. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be on site closing flood gates. Be careful along beaches and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by midday, Saturday 09/10/2021.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 13:15 PM on Friday 08/10/2021.

Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 12:30 PM and 02:00 PM on Friday 08/10/2021.

Plan driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded.

No flooding of properties is expected.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

The tide at 01:30 AM on Saturday 09/10/2021 is also currently forecast to reach Flood Alert Level. We will send an update once this current tide has passed.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.76mAOD at 17:00 on 08/10/21 and 4.62mAOD at 05:30 on 09/10/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is below normal for this time of year at 45 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain steady for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 09/10/21, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 01:15 PM on 08/10/2021. Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. Highest tide level is at 01:15 PM on 08/10/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Weather conditions are expected to produce large onshore waves. We are also expecting the high tide overnight tonight to exceed the Flood Alert threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Plan driving routes to avoid coastal roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 8:00 PM on 08/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible over the high tide on Friday evening. High water at Ilfracombe is at 8:13pm on Friday, but times of high water will vary slightly along the coast. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Impacts include minor flooding of roads and the possibility of some spray overtopping, but is not expected to result in property flooding. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. For those that use detailed tide information - the forecast high tide level at  Ilfracombe is 5.16 mAOD.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses. Flooding is likely to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. With drier and more settled weather now forecast lake levels will slowly fall but this flood alert may remain for today and much of tomorrow (9/10/2021). Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 09/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: Water levels remain high on Windermere, Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel due to several days of heavy rain earlier this week. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 09/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not expected.  High tide is expected at Trowlock Island at 5:15pm this afternoon (08/10/21). The river may over top banks and flood low lying land and footpaths. The predicted height of the tide is 4.95 - 5.15 metres.  The following high tide is expected at 5:45am.  The predicted height of the tide is 4.82 - 5.02 metres.  Based on recent forecasts it is likely that both tides will be towards the lower end of the ranges.  We continue to closely monitor the forecast and tide heights. Astronomical spring tides are peaking on Saturday (09/10/21) and fluvial levels are now falling slowly.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning (09/10/21).

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding Truro City
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening and for tomorrowâ€™s high spring tides. High water at Truro is at 6.57pm tonight (Thursday 07 October).  High tides for tomorrow (Friday 08 October), are at  7.20am and 7.38pm, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Force 4 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast, and may cause minor wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal areas.   

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Newlyn is 2.88 mAOD, this is 0.03 metres below astronomical tide level. 

From Saturday onwards the tide levels begin to decrease. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue an update on Saturday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 01:45 AM on 08/10/2021. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road, Arpley Bridge and Knutsford Road. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road, Arpley Bridge and Knutsford Road. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge between 02:15 AM and 02:45 AM on 08/10/2021. We are expecting higher than normal night time tides over the next two days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings. The weather isforecast to be largely calm with light winds and high pressure which is limiting tidal surge.  No significant rain is forecast. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 09/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Brockweir as a result of high spring tides.  Tides will be at their highest between 9:00 and 10:00 this evening Friday 8/10/21. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  We expect the risk of tidal flooding to ease after this evenings high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.5m to 7.6m at 9:30pm this evening 08/10/21, Newport 7.1m to 7.2m at 9:30pm this evening on 08/10/21.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads along the estuary which may be flooded.   
This message will be updated  by 09:00 tomorrow morning on 09/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding from River Roding in the Abridge, Loughton and Buckhurst Hill areas has now reduced. River levels will continue to fall further over the coming days and no further flooding to fields and roads is expected. There may be standing water seen for several days.

The River Arun at Pulborough is still high, following a very wet start to October. However, river levels are now slowly falling. Water will still affect fields and gardens, particularly near to Swan Bridge, Pulborough and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. At 15:30 on Friday (08/10/2021), the river at Houghton Bridge, Amberley, should not peak any higher than was seen on Wednesday lunchtime (06/10/2021), but water will still be close to the tops of the banks. Flooding is not currently expected this week in Arundel or Ford. Very little rain is forecast for the next 5 days and water levels at Pulborough will fall during that whole period. However, flows will not reduce significantly on the lower Arun until next week. From Saturday (09/10/2021), peak water levels at Houghton Bridge will fall by about 10 centimetres each day. Please keep flood protection products in place, if you have them, while minor residual flood impacts remain. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message: High spring tides remain until Sunday evening, but we do not expect these to reach Flood Alert levels.
High spring tides remain until Sunday evening, but we do not expect these to reach Flood Alert levels.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. The period of high spring tides continues for the next few days.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. The period of high spring tides continues for the next few days.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

The level of Derwentwater remains high following several days of rain earlier in the week. Areas most at risk of flooding include low lying land bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. The lake level is now dropping but remains above the Flood Warning level. We will continue to monitor water levels and it is likely this warning will be removed later today (8/10/2021). This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 09/10/2021, or as the situation changes.
